bestBHT.bht: Love is patient and kind, enduring wrongs without resentment and extending goodness to others. It does not boast or inflate itself with self-importance, promoting peace and harmony while counteracting envy and jealousy. Love restrains the ferocity of human nature, exhibiting forbearance and readiness to forgive. It does not act hastily or violently, but exercises moderation and meekness. This love, toward God and our neighbor, epitomizes patience, kindness, and humility.

Henry Alford: Longsuffering is the negative side, kindness the positive, of a loving temper.
Knows neither envy nor jealousy: both are included under it.
Vaunteth not itself... including 'all that a man takes upon himself, not from duty or necessity, but for the sake of self-exaltation.'
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: suffereth long—under provocations of evil from others. The negative side of love."
is kind—the positive side. Extending good to others. Compare with love's features here those of the 'wisdom from above'."
not puffed up—with party zeal, as some at Corinth were.
Albert Barnes: Charity suffereth long - Paul now proceeds to illustrate the 'nature' of love, or to show how it is exemplified. His illustrations are all drawn from its effect in regulating our conduct toward others, or our contact with them.

The 'reason' why he made use of this illustration, rather than its nature as evinced toward 'God,' was, probably, because it was especially necessary for them to understand in what way it should be manifested toward each other.

Besides, it is not the 'nature' of love to fill the mind in this manner. Pride, vanity, and even knowledge 1 Corinthians 8:1, may swell the mind with the conviction of self-importance; but love is humble, meek, modest, unobtrusive.
Marvin Vincent: The high charity which makes us servants Prompt to the counsel which controls the world." DANTE, "Paradiso," 21, 70, 71.
Heavens! How I showed off [ενεπερπερευσαμην] before my new auditor Pompey," and describes the various rhetorical tricks which he employed.
That swells with love the spirit well - disposed." " Paradiso, " 10, 144.
John Calvin: The first commendation of love is this — that, by patient endurance of many things, it promotes peace and harmony in the Church.
A third excellence is — that it counteracts emulation, the seed of all contentions.
Paul, therefore, ascribes to love moderation, and declares that it is a bridle to restrain men, that they may not break forth into ferocity, but may live together in a peaceable and orderly manner.
Philip Schaff: Love suffereth long. This long-suffering is the protracted endurance of wrong, such as is fitted to provoke resentment." (Commentary)

The word means to 'shew oneself benignant, gentle, good, meek.' Though used only here as a verb, it occurs frequently as an adjective, and precisely as it occurs here, in conjunction with long-suffering, the one being the negative, the other the positive side of the same quality; shewing that though there is no conjunction between them in the original, they were intended to go together." (Commentary)
Love vaunteth not itself; is not puffed up, does not ostentatiously parade its superiority to others, whether real or supposed, priding itself on it." (Commentary)
Archibald T. Robertson: Suffereth long. Late Koine word (Plutarch) from μακρος, long, θυμος, passion, ardour.
Is kind. From χρηστος (useful, gracious, kind) and that from χραομα, to use.
Envieth not. Present active indicative of ζηλοω (contraction οει=ο, same as subjunctive and optative forms).
John Gill: Charity suffereth long...but exercises forbearance, suffers long, and bears much, and is ready to forgive.
and is kind...easy and yielding to the tempers and humours of men; accommodates himself to their infirmities, capacities, manners, and circumstances.
charity envieth not...this grace, when in exercise, will not suffer a person to do.
John Wesley: The love of God, and of our neighbour for God's sake, is patient toward, all men. It, suffers all the weakness, ignorance, errors, and infirmities of the children of God; all the malice and wickedness of the children of the world: and all this, not only for a time, but to the end."
Love acteth not rashly — Does not hastily condemn any one; never passes a severe sentence on a slight or sudden view of things.
Nor does it ever act or behave in a violent, headstrong, or precipitate manner.

bhtAttempts.bht: Love is patient and kind. It endures wrongs without resentment and extends goodness to others, accommodating itself to their weaknesses and circumstances. Love does not boast or inflate itself with self-importance. It promotes peace and harmony, counteracts envy and jealousy, and restrains the ferocity of human nature. Love suffers long and bears much, exhibiting forbearance and readiness to forgive. It does not act hastily or violently, but exercises moderation and meekness. This love, both toward God and our neighbor, is the epitome of patience, kindness, and humility.

Love is patient and kind, enduring wrongs without resentment and extending goodness to others. It does not boast or inflate itself with self-importance, promoting peace and harmony while counteracting envy and jealousy. Love restrains the ferocity of human nature, exhibiting forbearance and readiness to forgive. It does not act hastily or violently, but exercises moderation and meekness. This love, toward God and our neighbor, epitomizes patience, kindness, and humility.

Love is patient and kind, suffering long and extending good to others. It does not envy or boast, nor does it promote self-exaltation. Instead, love promotes peace and harmony, restrains the selfishness of human nature, and counteracts jealousy and resentment. Love accommodates itself to the weaknesses and circumstances of others, showing forbearance and readiness to forgive. It does not act rashly or violently, but displays moderation and meekness. This love, both towards God and our neighbor, exemplifies patience, kindness, and humility.

Love is patient, kind, and longsuffering. It bears the hardships and provocations from others without resentment. Love extends goodness and is not characterized by envy or self-exaltation. Instead, it promotes peace and harmony, counteracts jealousy, and restrains selfishness. Love accommodates to the weaknesses and circumstances of others, offering forbearance and forgiveness. It does not act rashly or violently, but displays moderation and meekness. This love, towards both God and our neighbor, personifies patience, kindness, and humility.

Love encompasses both patience, which endures provocations and wrongs without resentment, and kindness, which extends good towards others. It is not characterized by envy or self-exaltation, but promotes peace and harmony, counteracting jealousy and restraining ferocity. Love accommodates itself to the weaknesses and circumstances of others, showing forbearance and readiness to forgive. It does not act rashly or violently, but demonstrates moderation and meekness. This love, both towards God and our neighbor, exemplifies the virtues of patience, kindness, and humility.
